Subject: Re : [neat] Re: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=vUAtOGA6OVy5JUGTHTYktwFOJS8lrYSQqUZ2fFAFmiqnKGEb5o3I

Peter, I understand your ideas and they have good motivation.  There
is a t=
ricky issue with interpreting the pattern output by a CPPN as
the morpholog=
y of an animal, and your thoughts make sense about ways
to make it more "mo=
rphological."  I find your simulations very
interesting and they are though=
t-provoking.

However, I cannot help but wonder whether there is a more fun=
damental
solution than trying to push the CPPN closer to a traditional iter=
ated
developmental paradigm.  Connective CPPNs in HyperNEAT are a good
exam=
ple of how it is possible that there is simply a better
*interpretation* of=
 a pattern than the most obvious one.  Perhaps the
story of connective CPPN=
s offers a good lesson in this context:  

For a long time we were scratchi=
ng our heads wondering how a spatial
pattern such as those output by regula=
r CPPNs could possibly translate
into a neural network in any straightforwa=
rd way.  It seemed that some
kind of ad hoc interpretation process or perha=
ps some very severe new
constraints might need to be introduced.  However, =
once I realized
that a connectivity pattern is nothing more than a spatial =
pattern in
higher-dimensional space, the problem became simple and elegantl=
y
solved by simple CPPNs without any special extensions.

So when I think a=
bout animal morphologies, part of me thinks that
there is a similar style o=
f solution that is based on simply using the
information output by a simple=
 CPPN in the right way.    After all, a
pattern in space is a pattern in sp=
ace and the key question may be how
to use it rather than how to get it.  A=
nimal morphologies have special
properties like joints and limb lengths.  I=
n some ways, they are not
only morphologies but perhaps more fundamentally =
jointed
connectivities.  Or perhaps something else.  But I think the first
=
question that needs to be answered is exactly what kind of structure
*is* a=
n animal morphology, and then the next question is whether that
type of str=
ucture is somehow isomorphic to a spatial pattern in a
useful way?  I am no=
t yet convinced there is not such an elegant
isomorphism in this case as we=
ll.

Nevertheless, iterated CPPNs and CPPNs that control morphological
grow=
th are still interesting dynamic systems and deserve to be
explored as well=
.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@.=
..>
wrote:
>
> Hi Ken, 
> 
> I was looking for an algorithm to develop anim=
al morphologies 
> (generally any kind of solid physics objects) with CPPNs=
. I found that 
> writing a conversion routine (CPPN snapshot -> object in =
world) is 
> very challenging and prone to many bugs and artifacts. I reali=
zed that 
> object building has to be done in another way - and I came up w=
ith 
> this simple idea. Suppose you have a set of small sticky cubes and y=
ou 
> want to build a house, a robot or whatever your imagination has. You =

> can do it like this - place one cube and fix its position in space. 
> S=
ee how it looks like and stick one more cube to it (where you want). 
> See=
 how the 2 cubes look like and then stick a third one. You can 
> stick the=
 cubes along the exposed sides of the fixed construction. 
> Iterate this f=
or enough time and you have the object. No separate 
> parts, everything ro=
ck-solid (although empty spaces can be constructed 
> inside), but has inte=
rnal structure with regularities, and the object 
> itself may be symmetric=
, segmented, or perhaps just a shitty blob. 
> These appear often. 
> 
> So=
 let me answer to your question about what kinds of shapes appear. I 
> act=
ually saw all of the biological development patterns, symmetry, 
> imperfec=
t symmetry, repetition and repetition with variation. In 
> particular, the=
 most interesting objects were created when I used 
> sin(x) and sin(y) wav=
es as input instead of the raw Cartesian 
> coordinate frames. They were se=
gmented and remarkably similar to 
> biological ones. 
> 
> The implementat=
ion I uploaded currently "divides" cells, placing a 
> random new cell in t=
he neighborhood of the cell of consideration. A 
> better solution is to it=
erate over the exposed surfaces and place new 
> cells if the CPPN says so.=
 
> 
> There are several issues about this idea. First of all, there is a 
=
> problem with the coordinates. We had a discussion with David about 
> the=
m, and I agree that I should just use the range of [-1 .. 1] for my 
> subs=
trate space. But the objects grow. So I have to either leave my 
> substrat=
e to [-infinite .. +infinite] or shrink the object every time 
> it gets la=
rger. Both doesn't work well, as too many garbage blobs 
> appear (is it no=
rmal?), so I am trying to find out an alternative. One 
> is that instead o=
f inputting coordinates to the CPPN, only time can be 
> used as input and =
possibly other information. I am thinking about this 
> one in particular:
=
> 
> Consider this situation, you are about to build something with the 
> =
sticky cubes. You start minimally and incrementally add structure. It 
> is=
 an iterative process, in which you first look at the intermediate 
> const=
ruction, then *decide* what is missing and place the missing 
> part. Then =
repeat this again until you run out of cubes. Like in NEAT, 
> but there is=
 nothing else in common. I know that it looks like a 
> process of explorat=
ion, but consider this.. You don't know how to 
> build make the final phen=
otype, but have a clear knowledge of the 
> exact *path* to building it, th=
e sense where things belong as you 
> build it? My idea is, that every futu=
re state of the object can be 
> viewed as a function of time and the curre=
nt state of the object. 
> Kinda confusing, isn't it? 
> 
> OK let's say th=
at an object A turns into an object B after addition of 
> one structural c=
omponent, which requires 1 time step. Then B =3D f(A). 
> Here is how you w=
ill produce the next object C: C =3D f(B). Then D =3D 
> f(C). And so on.. =

> 
> So the CPPN can take the role of that function f(x). The same CPPN ca=
n 
> be re-queried over and over again in time, producing a final phenotype=
 
> that is a function of time or just all of its intermediate forms 
> bef=
ore. The challenge is how to input the object's state in a 
> meaningful ma=
nner. Because the CPPN takes coordinate frames as inputs 
> and outputs poi=
nt intensity, how a whole object can be input into it? 
> Or is that a CPPN=
 at all? Is that just a form of recurrence without 
> future? I don't know.=
 
> 
> But really, when you look at a sequence of photos of developing embr=
yo 
> , you actually see something remarkably similar to complexifying 
> e=
volution of CPPNs. But instead of a genetic lineage through 
> crossovers a=
nd mutations, this is one single phenotype developing from 
> a single cell=
 to a mature form. I believe that CPPNs and even just 
> regular ANNs can a=
bstract the transitions from one object state to 
> another very compactly.=
 Because it is only adding structure, the 
> phenotype increases in complex=
ity over time even without having to 
> complexify the CPPN itself. It only=
 has to see what it did so far and 
> decide what to do next. It is a hypot=
hetical idea, I haven't even 
> tried to implement such a thing, I actually=
 just talk about it, there 
> are many challenges, perhaps it is totally st=
upid, but I believe that 
> it may be a path to an incredible AE capable of=
 creating highly 
> complex phenotypes from very compact genomes. What do y=
ou think about 
> it? 
> 
> Peter C
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenn=
eth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter, you make a good point that t=
here is a challenge in 
> interpreting
> > arbitrary CPPN patterns as disti=
nct physical objects.  I think ideas
> > like yours are indeed important to=
 explore to potentially address 
> the
> > issue, and I found your shape-ev=
olving novelty search program along
> > those lines very interesting.  Sinc=
e you have most experience with 
> the
> > idea, I am curious, do you get t=
he sense after playing with it a lot
> > that the patterns that come out ar=
e indeed sufficiently diverse and
> > regular to potentially represent anim=
al morphologies?  Or does there
> > seem to be anything lacking from the ou=
tput of such systems?
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "p=
etar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>
> > wrote:
> > >
> > > I'd like to poi=
nt out that CPPNs can be combined effectively with 
> > > cellular growth m=
odels. Because the cells need the answer to the 
> > > question "Who am I?"=
, the CPPN can provide that info without any 
> > > interaction between cel=
ls. It can also provide instructions about, 
> for 
> > > example "Should I=
 divide or not? Should I change my type?". 
> > > While it seems like an ov=
erkill, because CPPNs already abstract 
> this 
> > > away without having t=
o introduce time for development, the 
> patterns 
> > > generated are hard=
 to interpret as distinct physical objects. 
> > > Especially in cases of r=
epeating patterns. But objects generated 
> with 
> > > cellular growth ins=
tructed by CPPNs produce only a single object, 
> all 
> > > with its disti=
nct parts and regularities. And not ripped apart 
> with 
> > > artifacts a=
s it would be after converting it from a CPPN snapshot 
> > > image. One mi=
ght say that such objects can still be infinte in 
> size, 
> > > but it is=
 easy to put a limitation on the number of cells or cell 
> > > divisions. =
It is also possible to make the limit dynamic, more 
> complex 
> > > CPPNs=
 producing phenotypes with more cells.
> > > 
> > > Peter
> > > 
> > > --- =

> > >=
 > Alexandre, thank you for bringing up reaction-diffusion systems.  
> > >=
 You
> > > > make a good point- my statement was too broad, in part because=

> > > > "cellular growth model" is a fairly ambiguous term that can
> > > =
> potentially refer to many types of systems.  
> > > > 
> > > > Just to cl=
arify my statement, I was responding the line of 
> > > discussion
> > > > =
with Peter about encodings that actually create distinct bodily 
> > > shap=
es
> > > > that are self-contained and have clear structural boundaries 
> =
(which
> > > > reaction-diffusion systems tend not to produce; rather they =

> produce
> > > > wallpaper-like patterns).  Often when growth-based model=
s are 
> used 
> > > to
> > > > define actual bodies with distinct borders,=
 they are studied in 
> the
> > > > context of blobs with a particular focu=
s on how the blob knows 
> when 
> > > to
> > > > stop growing so that a bo=
rder shape can be created.  That kind 
> of
> > > > systems goes along with=
 the "skin" issue that we were 
> discussing.
> > > > 
> > > > Nevertheless=
, the field is quite broad and there are many 
> possible
> > > > interesti=
ng examples of such systems.  If I could revisit my
> > > > statement, I wo=
uld reword it such as to avoid implying any 
> sweeping
> > > > generalizat=
ion.
> > > > 
> > > > ken
> > > >
